intro: Matelea hastulata, commonly known as the arrowleaf mallow, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton, and is characterized by its showy, pink to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and arid environments, showcasing adaptations to drought conditions. Its leaves are palmately lobed, giving it a distinctive appearance, and it produces capsule fruits that contain numerous seeds. Matelea hastulata is often found in desertscrub and chaparral habitats, contributing to the biodiversity of these ecosystems.
